‚ÄúThis measure supports Albertans‚Äô rights to clean air, water and soil, with the ability to hold the government accountable for environmental decision-making, including appeals or investigations when environmental laws are broken.‚Äù #abpoli #environment 
A major plank in our platform for the forthcoming campaign: An Environmental Bill Of Rights for all Albertans! 
In committee for Bill #S203, a CPC M.P. just said seeing whales in captivity is the same as seeing them in the wild. Um, no, not even close my friend. Not even close. #FreeWilly 
Hardie asks about helping whales who are injured. Sinclair explains that the bill allows legitimate rescue and rehabilitation if the need arises. 
NDP MP Gord Johns asks Dr Visser about the horrible neurotic abnormal she has seen in captive whales. Really heartbreaking to hear about whales banging heads against the wall, chew on concrete, regurgitate food, hyper aggression, etc. 
He concludes by saying that ‚Äúin the long run society will be much better off if we start to treat other creatures that we we would like to be treated.‚Äù TRUE! 
Now Senator Murray Sinclair is up. He brings up Marineland‚Äôs supposed concerns about being charged after pregnant belugas give birth. He points out that this would NOT be an offence under the bill. (Here‚Äôs a primer on the tricks Marineland is trying 
May turns it over to Dr. Ingrid Visser, a cetacean expert. She is speaking now about the scientific evidence showing that confining whales in tanks is very cruel to them. Points out that laws in Canada do not adequately protect cetaceans right now. So ban captivity. 
May: If we make a single amendment to this bill, it will kill it. Tens of thousands of Canadians want to see this bill passed and we need to do it. 
May says it is hard to think of another bill that has been studied more. Over 17 meetings in the Senate and 30 meetings. ‚ÄúTime for study is over, the time for passing is now.‚Äù

column1: On behalf of all New Democrats

column1: I'm deeply disappointed in @AndrewScheer. His refusal to denounce these divisive comments sends a dangerous message. Children of diverse backgrounds across Canada pick up on these messages. Right now
column2: they need to hear that their country wants more of themselves
column3: not less.

column1: Diversity is the fisherman in Prince Edward County passing his business onto a young refugee. Diversity is the response we saw from people in Quebec City following the mosque shooting. Diversity is knowing that beyond Indigenous Peoples
column2: all Canadians are immigrants.

column1: In a time when the voices against diversity are getting stronger
column2: we must do more to embrace and empower the voiceless. More diversity will not destroy what it means to be Canadian ‚Äì it is foundational to who we are
column3: it is a fundamental Canadian value.

column1: To those who feel targeted by these comments
column2: I want you to know that you're very much Canadian
column3: and you strengthen all of us. Canada‚Äôs identity is based on inclusion
column4: and our unyielding belief in lifting each other up in response to attempts to divide us.

column1: When you are told by some that Canada wants less of you
column2: I understand the isolation you feel. I understand the uncertainty
column3: risk
column4: vulnerability and pain it creates. Comments like these make you feel like there's something wrong with you

column1: THREAD: I‚Äôve waited to respond to Maxime Bernier's comments to see if @AndrewScheer would do the responsible thing denounce these divisive words. He has not. To everyone that belongs to a diverse community ‚Äì who's been told you don‚Äôt belong ‚Äì I‚Äôve been in your shoes
column2: I get it.

column1: Of particular note: U.S. immigration judges and asylum officers use the human rights reports to evaluate the credibility of an applicant's fear of persecution. Human rights reports that contradict an asylum seeker in virtually any way can be fatal to an asylum application.

column1: Regional economies and industries that depend on natural resources and favorable climate conditions, such as agriculture, tourism, and fisheries, are vulnerable to the growing impacts of climate change.

More frequent and intense extreme weather and climate-related events, as well as changes in average climate conditions, are expected to continue to damage infrastructure, ecosystems, and social systems that provide essential benefits to communities.

With continued growth in emissions at historic rates, annual losses in some economic sectors are projected to reach hundreds of billions of dollars by the end of the century‚Äîmore than the current GDP of many U.S. states.

column1: The Court gutted the Voting Rights Act in 2013 by ruling that states with a history of suppression no longer needed federal approval to change their voting laws. Kavanaugh's record indicates he would help a new majority kill the VRA entirely and approve even more suppression.

Voter fraud‚Äîthe justification for voter ID laws‚Äîhas also been proven to be a virtually nonexistent problem. A recent Brennan Center report noted that an American is more likely to be struck by lightning than to impersonate someone else at the polls.
